articles.headline: Financial Crisis, Over and Already Forgotten
articles.snippet: Amnesia seemed to be in force as the House Financial Services Committee met this week for a hearing on “the dangers” of financial regulation.
articles.abstract: Amnesia seemed to be in force as the House Financial Services Committee met this week for a hearing on “the dangers” of financial regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael S. Barr, a law professor at the University of Michigan who was an assistant Treasury secretary when the financial crisis was at its worst, is working on a book titled “Five Ways the Financial System Will Fail Next Time.”

articles.headline: Competing Visions for Russia’s Economic Future
articles.snippet: The St. Petersburg International Economic Forum aims to woo foreign investment, but the event is under a cloud this year as Russia stands on the verge of recession.
articles.abstract: The St. Petersburg International Economic Forum aims to woo foreign investment, but the event is under a cloud this year as Russia stands on the verge of recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — A panel at an annual economic forum here was deeply divided over the direction of the Russian economy. The isolationists in the group favored relying on state banks for its financing needs. Others called for Russia to deepen its ties with China, while a different contingent said global trade and commerce remain critical.

articles.headline: A Hedge Fund Highflier Comes Back to Earth
articles.snippet: Crispin Odey, whose hedge fund’s fortunes have risen and fallen in recent years, drew attention with extravagant plans for a chicken coop.
articles.abstract: Crispin Odey, whose hedge fund’s fortunes have risen and fallen in recent years, drew attention with extravagant plans for a chicken coop.
articles.lead_paragraph: ENGLISH BICKNOR, England — The chickens of the one percent could roost comfortably here.

articles.headline: Facebook’s New Privacy Mascot: The Zuckasaurus
articles.snippet: On Thursday, Facebook showed off a blue dinosaur character that will become the privacy ambassador on the social network. But the dinosaur could follow in the path of Microsoft’s Clippy, and Twitter’s Fail Whale, both of which were meant to help u...
articles.abstract: On Thursday, Facebook showed off a blue dinosaur character that will become the privacy ambassador on the social network. But the dinosaur could follow in the path of Microsoft’s Clippy, and Twitter’s Fail Whale, both of which were meant to help users and ended up being hated by people.

articles.headline: From Virginia, Chasing Down Credit Suisse
articles.snippet: The long arm of United States prosecutors in Alexandria, Va., has led to cases against banks and other financial players across the country and the globe.
articles.abstract: The long arm of United States prosecutors in Alexandria, Va., has led to cases against banks and other financial players across the country and the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of miles from Credit Suisse’s Madison Avenue office tower and an ocean away from its headquarters in Zurich, the bank found an unlikely opponent in Alexandria, Va.

articles.headline: U.S. Case Offers Glimpse Into China’s Hacker Army
articles.snippet: Many of the hackers employed by the Chinese government are men in their 20s and 30s who have been trained at universities run by the People’s Liberation Army.
articles.abstract: Many of the hackers employed by the Chinese government are men in their 20s and 30s who have been trained at universities run by the People’s Liberation Army.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — One man accused of being a hacker for the Chinese military, Wang Dong, better known as UglyGorilla, wrote in a social media profile that he did not “have much ambition” but wanted “to wander the world with a sword, an idiot.”

articles.headline: As Publishers Fight Amazon, Books Vanish
articles.snippet: Seeking ever-higher payments from publishers to bolster its anemic bottom line, Amazon is holding books and authors hostage on two continents by delaying shipments and raising prices.
articles.abstract: Seeking ever-higher payments from publishers to bolster its anemic bottom line, Amazon is holding books and authors hostage on two continents by delaying shipments and raising prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon’s power over the publishing and bookselling industries is unrivaled in the modern era. Now it has started wielding its might in a more brazen way than ever before.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Class Field Trip Stops at a Local Pawnshop
articles.snippet: Brian Page, a teacher in Ohio, took students in his personal finance and economics class out into the real world for lessons on high-cost lending.
articles.abstract: Brian Page, a teacher in Ohio, took students in his personal finance and economics class out into the real world for lessons on high-cost lending.
articles.lead_paragraph: READING, Ohio — The last time Brian Page had to file the paperwork to evict a tenant from a rental property he and his wife own, he noticed all the check-cashing services and pawn shops on his drive home from the courthouse. A clerk tipped him off to what was going on: Every day, lots of people leave court with checks they’ve received in legal settlements. They often stop to cash their checks right away, paying a big fee for the privilege, and then go shopping with the money.

articles.headline: U.S. Gains in a Spat With China Over Tariffs
articles.snippet: The ruling by the World Trade Organization gives the Obama administration another opportunity to portray itself as being willing to confront Beijing on trade issues.
articles.abstract: The ruling by the World Trade Organization gives the Obama administration another opportunity to portray itself as being willing to confront Beijing on trade issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The World Trade Organization sided with the United States on Friday in a dispute over punitive Chinese tariffs on American exports of cars and sport utility vehicles.
articles.byline: By Annie Lowrey and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: As Summer Driving Beckons, Gas Prices Are All Over the Map
articles.snippet: The Memorial Day weekend begins the summer driving season and sharp differences in gasoline prices around the country reflect all the complexities of the global energy markets.
articles.abstract: The Memorial Day weekend begins the summer driving season and sharp differences in gasoline prices around the country reflect all the complexities of the global energy markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With the Memorial Day weekend representing the beginning of the summer driving season, it might be a good time to plan a trip to the Gulf Coast or the Rocky Mountains. Gasoline prices in the nation’s midsection should be 10 to 50 cents cheaper per gallon than a year ago.

articles.headline: Guantánamo Inmate’s Case Reignites Fight Over Detentions
articles.snippet: The long struggle over Guantánamo Bay is again reverberating as a Federal District Court judge lifted an order barring the force-feeding of a Syrian detainee.
articles.abstract: The long struggle over Guantánamo Bay is again reverberating as a Federal District Court judge lifted an order barring the force-feeding of a Syrian detainee.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The seemingly unending struggle over Guantánamo Bay — the prison President Obama vowed to close shortly after he was sworn in — is again reverberating over an “anguishing” case of force-feeding a Syrian detainee.
